author: Jak Connor
title: World's largest EV battery company founder says Elon Musk's bet on battery tech will fail
text:
Elon Musk made a big bet on the battery technology known as 4680 cylindrical cell technology, making as many as 100 million of them. Unfortunately, these Tesla 4680 cells are supposed to have "[five times](https://www.theverge.com/2020/9/22/21449238/tesla-electric-car-battery-tabless-cells-day-elon-musk)" more energy capacity than what was announced back in September this year.
A [report by The Information](https://www.theinformation.com/articles/teslas-future-was-all-about-the-battery-until-it-wasnt) revealed Musk set a deadline for Tesla employees to complete the stack of batteries before the end of the year. Notably, these batteries are the bread and butter for Tesla as they are used in some of the company's electric vehicles, such as the Cybertruck. However, Robin Zeng, the founder of the world's biggest EV battery company, Contemporary Amperex Technology (CATL), [told Reuters](https://www.reuters.com/business/autos-transportation/china-battery-giant-catl-would-build-us-plant-if-trump-allows-it-2024-11-13/) that Musk's big bet on 4680 cylindrical cell technology "is going to fail and never be successful."
CATL batteries are used in some Tesla vehicles and are also used in other branded EVs such as Ford and Mustang. However, the company specializes in a different type of battery technology called lithium iron phosphate batteries (LFP), which can't provide as much as the cylindrical cell units. Zeng also spoke about meeting with Musk and discussing batteries, to which he said he wasn't impressed with the CEO's knowledge on the subject. Zeng did acknowledge that he was impressed with Musk's knowledge on chips, software, hardware, and "mechanical things".

author: Oxygen8America
title: How Often Should You Do Hyperbaric Oxygen Therapy?
text: How Often Should You Do Hyperbaric Oxygen Therapy? Hyperbaric oxygen therapy (HBOT) has gained traction for its promising health benefits. Many people turn to HBOT for enhanced healing, improved energy levels, and recovery support for various conditions. However, one of the most common questions is: How often should you undergo this therapy? The answer depends on a few key factors, including your specific health needs, goals, and medical guidance. Let’s explore these considerations and uncover how frequently you should plan your HBOT sessions. Understanding Hyperbaric Oxygen Therapy Hyperbaric oxygen therapy is a treatment where you breathe pure oxygen inside a pressurized chamber, called a [hyperbaric chamber](https://oxygen8america.com/hyperbaric-chambers/). The added pressure helps more oxygen dissolve into your blood and tissues. This boost promotes cell repair, helps combat bacteria, and speeds up healing. HBOT is popular among those seeking wellness benefits, athletes recovering from injuries, and individuals dealing with chronic conditions like diabetes, brain injuries, and infections. Its applications vary widely, and so does the recommended frequency of treatments. Key Factors that Influence Frequency of HBOT The right frequency of HBOT sessions isn’t one-size-fits-all. Here’s what affects how often you should consider HBOT: - Your Health Condition: Certain conditions, like severe infections, may require more intensive treatment. Meanwhile, for wellness and general recovery, fewer sessions may suffice. - Therapy Goals: Whether you’re seeking quick recovery, enhanced performance, or long-term health benefits can influence session frequency. - Doctor’s Recommendation: Always consult a healthcare professional for personalized guidance. They will assess your needs and advise accordingly. Let’s break down recommended schedules based on common uses of hyperbaric oxygen therapy. Recommended HBOT Frequency for Different Purposes 1. For Chronic Health Conditions If you’re managing a chronic condition like diabetes, non-healing wounds, or radiation injuries, HBOT can be an effective part of your treatment plan. Typically, for chronic conditions, more sessions are recommended: - Frequency: 3 to 5 times a week - Duration: 1–2 hours per session - Total Course: Often 20 to 40 sessions or more, depending on the severity Patients with these conditions may notice significant improvement with consistent treatments. The high frequency is designed to help your body utilize oxygen for healing and cell repair more effectively. 2. For Injury Recovery and Post-Surgery Healing Athletes, or anyone recovering from surgery, may benefit from HBOT to speed up healing and reduce inflammation. By increasing oxygen levels in the body, HBOT supports cell recovery and promotes faster healing times. - Frequency: 3 times a week - Duration: About 1 hour per session - Total Course: 10 to 20 sessions, based on progress Many athletes or post-surgical patients experience faster recovery times and reduced pain with HBOT. Consistent sessions over a short period allow for concentrated benefits without prolonged breaks. 3. For Wellness and Preventative Care Some people use HBOT as a preventative measure or for general wellness. The aim here is to boost energy levels, support immunity, and maintain overall health. - Frequency: 1 to 2 times a week - Duration: 1-hour sessions - Total Course: Ongoing as desired, but usually around 10 to 15 sessions initially In this context, HBOT can be seen as a wellness “booster.” Weekly sessions maintain a steady increase in oxygen levels, which may enhance mood, focus, and energy. After the initial set of sessions, many people choose to continue once or twice a month. 4. For Brain Health and Cognitive Benefits Emerging research suggests that HBOT may have benefits for brain health. Conditions such as traumatic brain injury (TBI) or cognitive decline related to aging may benefit from regular sessions. - Frequency: 3 to 4 times a week - Duration: 1–1.5 hours per session - Total Course: 30–40 sessions, depending on improvement HBOT’s potential to support neuroplasticity, increase blood flow to the brain, and reduce inflammation makes it an appealing option. If you’re pursuing HBOT for cognitive health, close monitoring by a healthcare provider is essential to track progress. What to Expect During Hyperbaric Oxygen Therapy Sessions Each session begins with you entering a sealed hyperbaric chamber, either soft-sided or hard. The chamber pressurizes gradually, reaching a level above standard atmospheric pressure. You’ll then breathe 100% oxygen. Most sessions last about 1 to 1.5 hours, although times may vary based on the treatment purpose. During the session, some people read, listen to music, or rest. The pressurization might cause a slight popping sensation in your ears, similar to the feeling during a plane ascent. How to Know if You’re Overdoing HBOT While hyperbaric therapy is generally safe, there’s a limit to how much oxygen your body can safely absorb over time. Overdoing HBOT can lead to side effects such as oxygen toxicity, ear discomfort, or fatigue. If you experience any of the following symptoms, it might be a sign to reduce frequency or pause treatment: - Dizziness or nausea - Shortness of breath - Blurred vision or ringing in the ears - Extreme fatigue Regular check-ups with a healthcare provider can help prevent these effects. They can also adjust your frequency based on your body’s response. Finding the Right Balance The key to HBOT’s effectiveness lies in consistency, not overuse. By finding the right balance, you can maximize benefits while minimizing risks. Here are a few tips to ensure you’re on the right track: - Start with a Consultation: Before beginning HBOT, consult with a licensed provider. They will recommend a plan based on your health and goals. - Listen to Your Body: Pay attention to how you feel after each session. Minor fatigue is normal, but persistent discomfort should be discussed with your provider. - Adjust as Needed: Over time, your frequency might change. Regular check-ins with your healthcare team ensure you’re not overloading your system with oxygen. Summing Up Hyperbaric oxygen therapy offers a versatile approach to healing, wellness, and recovery. The right frequency for [hyperbaric oxygen therapy](https://oxygen8america.com/hyperbaric-oxygen-therapy/) depends on your individual needs, health conditions, and goals. While some conditions benefit from frequent sessions, others require only occasional maintenance. Finding your ideal HBOT schedule may take time, but with guidance from healthcare providers and by listening to your body, you can determine a routine that enhances your health without overdoing it. Hyperbaric oxygen therapy, when used thoughtfully, can become a powerful part of your wellness toolkit.

author: Samson Tamijani
title: BOIL NOTICE | City of Hominy continues boil notice after severe weather
text: HOMINY, Okla. — The May 6, EF-4 tornado began on the outskirts of the city of Hominy, which did not experience much damage but did go days without power — and still does not have drinkable water. The city issued a boil water notice May 5, after its water supply from Hominy Municipal Lake tested positive for [E. coli,](https://www.cdc.gov/ecoli/index.html) but the Oklahoma [Department of Environmental Quality](https://www.deq.ok.gov/divisions/wqd/) couldn't get investigators to check its testing systems until Thursday because the plant was also without power the first half of the week. The city announced Thursday afternoon the boil water notice will continue through at least the weekend as it follows guidance from DEQ. In the meantime, Hominy Fire & Rescue has collected crates of water bottles and water buffaloes with help from American Legion Post 142 for anyone who needs them. In the first day and a half, volunteers said the number of residents to come by numbered in the hundreds. "That's what we do. We take care of our communities," John Hamilton of Post 142 in Hominy said. "We help where there's a need. We fill that need, or try to." Residents receiving the emergency bottles like Deborah Martin and Maria Sivils told 2 News there was never a time they didn't trust the water until now. They also only regained electricity Wednesday night. "It was terrifying really. You just see nothing but blackness," Sivils said. "We're managing. We are adapting. It's just part of the situation, you can't do anything about it," Martin said. Previous coverage >>> [BOIL ORDER: E. coli in Hominy water causing disruptions](https://www.kjrh.com/news/local-news/boil-order-e-coli-in-hominy-water-causing-disruptions) The contamination continues to disrupt daily life in town, residents said. Hominy Public Schools moved to distance learning temporarily due to the dirty water and storm damage, but its superintendent said Thursday the district will tough out for the final weeks of the semester. After all, it could be worse. "We're getting by. We're going to do it. At least we're not as bad as Barnsdall," Sivils said. "We are blessed we didn't get hit like poor Barnsdall," Martin added. [Click here to donate to the tornado disaster relief fund.](https://www.kjrh.com/tornado-relief-donations) Stay in touch with us anytime, anywhere -- - Download our free app for [Apple](http://bit.ly/2wfyiphoneapp), [Android](http://bit.ly/kjrhandroid)and [Kindle](http://amzn.to/1dLTWVt)devices. - Sign up for daily [newsletters emailed to you](http://www.kjrh.com/account/manage-email-preferences) [Like us on Facebook](https://www.facebook.com/kjrhtv) [Follow us on Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/2worksforyou/) [SUBSCRIBE on YouTube](https://www.youtube.com/@2NewsOklahoma)

author: VNExplorer
title: Real estate boss breaks her silence after worker was stabbed to death and colleague wounded in 'random' attack at Plympton office
text:
Julie Seed killed in Adelaide real estate officeAlleged killer recently released from hospital READ MORE: Heroic act of mother Susan Scardigno to try and save her colleague Julie Seed
The boss of a woman stabbed to death in what police allege was a random attack by a man just released from a mental health facility wants blame-shifting for the tragedy to stop.
Shaun Michaels Dunk, 30, is accused of storming into REAL Estate Agents Group in Plympton, Adelaide, on December 20 and attacking staff with a knife.
Property manager Julie Seed, 38, died at the scene, while team leader Susan Scardigno, 50, was critically injured and is recovering at Royal Adelaide Hospital.
Dunk, who has been charged with one count each of murder and attempted murder, was released from a mental health facility that morning.
He had also been discharged from hospital on December 18, despite allegedly warning police a fortnight earlier he had been hallucinating and was worried he might hurt someone.
Property manager Julie Seed, 38, died at REAL Estate Agents Group in Plympton, Adelaide, on December 20 after Shaun Michaels Dunk, 30, allegedly stormed the office armed with a knife. Ms Seed is pictured with fiancé, Chris Smith
REAL Estate Agents Group principal Ally Comley took to Facebook on Sunday, paying tribute to her employees and calling for support for mental health care workers.
‘We must honour dear Julie’s life and ensure this tragedy is the turning point to fast-track an immediate overhaul of the SA Mental Health System that has utterly failed so many,’ Ms Comley wrote.
‘There is no person at fault here.
‘We cannot blame the unfortunate medical staff who released [Dunk] – these too are real people who I’m sure must also be badly affected right now. I feel for them.
‘They are duty-bound to follow processes. The blame lies entirely in the inadequacies of the broken system they work within, not them personally.’
Ms Comley described Ms Seed and Ms Scardigno as like ‘sisters’ to their colleagues at the agency and ‘an integral part of our REAL family who we love wholly’.
‘Julie’s family are suffering incredibly with the pain of their loss and we feel deeply for them,’ Ms Comley wrote.
‘Sue was severely injured but pulled through due to her inner strength and the hand of God.
Team leader Susan Scardigno, 50, was critically injured in the alleged attack by Sean Michaels Dunk and is recovering at the Royal Adelaide Hospital. A friend of Ms Scardigno (above) said she sustained her injuries while trying to protect her colleague
‘She is an inspirational woman and is already making a remarkable recovery due to her tenacity.
‘But her emotional healing I’m sure, will be lengthy. We will stand by all of them in every way possible.’
REAL Estate Agents Group principal Ally Comley (above) paid tribute to Ms Seed and Ms Scardigno on Facebook
A friend of Ms Scardigno previously told Daily Mail Australia she had sustained her injuries while trying to protect Ms Seed.
Ms Comley thanked those who had come to her employees’ aid including paramedics and police officers.
‘We are completely indebted to our co-tenants in the building for their brave and timely intervention,’ she wrote. ‘Without question they saved Sue’s life.’
Ms Comley said Ms Seed’s death and Ms Scardigno’s injuries had deeply affected their colleagues’ families, friends and clients.
‘Such tragedies never just stay within a few,’ she wrote. ‘They have a ripple effect and in this case, the emotional damage to many families is immense.
‘We have been overwhelmed and humbled by messages of support from our clients, landlords, tenants, and our neighbouring businesses – your kindness and beautiful messages have touched us.’
Dunk spent the night of December 19 in the care of the Urgent Mental Health Care Centre on Grenfell Street in Adelaide’s central business district before being let out two hours before the alleged attack.
Shaun Michaels Dunk, 30, (left) has been accused of storming into the REAL Estate Agents Group in Plympton, Adelaide, on December 20 and attacking workers with a knife and hammer
He had been detained under the Mental Health Act on December 5 after showing up to a police station claiming that he was experiencing hallucinations of people threatening to kill him, according to The Advertiser.
SA Health has launched a review into their processes and the state’s chief psychiatrist will be reviewing the circumstances around Dunk’s treatment and discharge.
Dunk appeared via video link before the Adelaide Magistrates Court on December 21.
He did not apply for bail and will remain in custody until March when he is due to to face the court again.
A friend of Ms Seed’s fiancé, Chris Smith, launched a GoFundMe campaign to help her family cover flights from the United Kingdom and other funeral costs.
Ms Seed has two daughters aged 12 and 18, and got engaged to Mr Smith a year ago.
